docs.snippet: The Oscar show is always a mess, but to Oscar Ninnies, its our mess....
docs.lead_paragraph: In 1994, the Bagger met a girl -- cute, rough and ready, and just gullible enough to buy the baloney he was spouting. They lived in Minnesota and on the spur of the moment decided to drive to Taos, N.M., for some skiing. They took her Saab because he was driving junk at the time, and ripped down there in nothing flat. Their accommodations in an old adobe building in town were gorgeous, but lacked a television. No big deal, except, except, it was Oscar weekend. He admitted he HAD to see the show and they frantically raced all over town on Sunday until they found a bar where it was showing. The Bagger enjoyed the proceedings, give or take Tom Hanks preachy best actor speech for "Philadelphia." (Hey, we were all young and full of beans back then.)
docs.abstract: The Oscar show is always a mess, but to Oscar Ninnies, its our mess.

docs.snippet: Will the Bagger and his friends ever free themselves from their Oscar addiction?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lewis Beale is working out some issues over at The Reeler. Sounds like he and the Bagger might need to head down to a church basement with some bad coffee, stale donuts and like-afflicted people
docs.abstract: Will the Bagger and his friends ever free themselves from their Oscar addiction?

docs.snippet: The Bagger and Geena Davis; a match made in heaven, or at least online....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger read about Oscar.com's perfect Oscar date gimmick and took both the bait and the quiz. He ended up with Geena Davis, who is both too tall for him and so far out of his league that the distance cannot be measured. Then he read the comment that came with the answer.
docs.abstract: The Bagger and Geena Davis; a match made in heaven, or at least online.

docs.snippet: Neither Borat nor his creator will be at the big show this year....
docs.lead_paragraph: Looking for a little Borat to go with your best picture watch? Do not stay tuned, says the Envelope. "He was asked," Oscar broadcast producer Laura Ziskin said Friday, "but he declined."
docs.abstract: Neither Borat nor his creator will be at the big show this year.

docs.snippet: Forest Whitaker on shooting "The Last King of Scotland" in Uganda....
docs.lead_paragraph: "The Last King of Scotland," the rare movie about Africa that to use the continent for something besides a backdrop for the great white man theory of history, is a hit in Uganda. Forest Whitaker, who played Idi Amin and will likely reap an Oscar to go with his smashing reviews, told The Associated Press that filming the movie there made all the difference in the world. It allowed him "to be surrounded by people who have experienced Amin, who knew the situation emotionally and internally," Mr. Whitaker said. "All of the people were helpful in trying to guide us to the truth."
docs.abstract: Forest Whitaker on shooting "The Last King of Scotland" in Uganda.

docs.snippet: A global symposium on Oscar matters....
docs.lead_paragraph: USA Today's excellent Oscar blog, Red Carpet Report -- all hail MSM brethren -- picked up on a bit of a global symposium that the BBC ran on all things Oscar.
docs.abstract: A global symposium on Oscar matters.

docs.snippet: Clint Eastwood and Terry Gross, together again....
docs.lead_paragraph: The overlap between Oscar watchers and regular listeners to NPR's "Fresh Air" is probably very small, but the Bagger happens to be in that small sweet spot. Long after he got home the other night, he listened to Terry Gross and Clint Eastwood, two soft-spoken people who say a lot every time they open up their mouths, talking about his last two movies and beyond.
docs.abstract: Clint Eastwood and Terry Gross, together again.

docs.snippet: All-Star weekend on the Vegas Strip is one thing. The N.B.A. with its makeup removed on a Tuesday night in January is another....
docs.lead_paragraph: All-Star weekend on the Vegas Strip is one thing. The N.B.A. with its makeup removed on a Tuesday night in January is another.

headline.main: A Marriage Sure to Fizzle Under Lights of Las Vegas
headline.print_headline: A Marriage Sure to Fizzle Under Lights Of Las Vegas

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    U.S. Reports Al QaedaIs Training in Pakistan  Senior leaders of Al Qaeda operating from Pakistan have re-established significant control over their once-battered worldwide terror network and over the past year have set up a b...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 U.S. Reports Al QaedaIs Training in Pakistan Senior leaders of Al Qaeda operating from Pakistan have re-established significant control over their once-battered worldwide terror network and over the past year have set up a band of training camps in the tribal regions near the Afghan border, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials. A1 The Iranian Foreign Ministry charged that Sunni insurgents from Iran used Pakistan as a base to plan a bombing that killed 11 people and wounded more than 30 in the southeastern border city of Zahedan last week, and said it had demanded an explanation from the Pakistani ambassador. A8 Rice Tries to Salvage Talks Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she planned to continue to push a peace initiative between Israel and the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, even though a new Palestinian unity government did not recognize Israel or renounce violence, conditions that Israel and the United States have demanded. A8 2 Car Bombs Kill 60 in Baghdad After Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki called the opening steps of a security crackdown in Baghdad a ''dazzling success,'' two car bombs in a market killed at least 60 people. The explosions occurred within seconds of each other, said witnesses, and were probably detonated in cars already parked in the area, Iraqi officials said. A6 A draft version of the long-awaited law that would govern the development of Iraqi oil fields and the distribution of oil revenues has been submitted to Iraq's cabinet, the first step toward approving the legislation, members of a senior negotiating committee said. A6 Deal on Australian Detainee The Australian foreign minister said his government had reached a deal to allow David Hicks, who has been held at the American military base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to return to Australia by the end of the year. If he is found guilty by a military tribunal in the United States, he would be allowed to serve out his sentence in an Australian prison. A7 Israeli Police Official Resigns Israel's police commissioner resigned after an investigative committee severely criticized his actions in a 1999 case involving an Israeli crime family. A8 8 Die in Afghan Copter Crash An American twin-rotor Chinook helicopter suffered engine failure and crashed in southeastern Afghanistan, killing 8 soldiers and injuring 14, said a spokesman at Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul. All 22 on board were Americans, he said. A8 NATIONAL A10-13 JetBlue Trying to Weather Cancellation Storm In the wake of mass cancellations that began when an ice storm hit the Eastern United States, the founder and chief executive of JetBlue Airways, calling himself ''humiliated and mortified,'' will announce a recovery plan that would pay customers for every hour they were stuck on a plane. A1 Some Clinton Foes on Sidelines Time and a shifting political environment have taken some of the energy out of the longstanding campaign against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and some big money Republicans are remaining neutral as she campaigns for president. A1 No More Kitchen Campaigning? The days in which presidential candidates meet Iowa voters in kitchens and living rooms may be numbered. Celebrity candidates, busloads of reporters and intense voter interest are curbing traditional methods of stumping in the state with the first presidential caucuses. A11 Final Clash in Leak Trial Closing arguments in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. will offer a final face-off between the trial's leading adversaries, chief prosecutor Patrick J. Fitzgerald and Theodore V. Wells Jr., Mr. Libby's lawyer. A13 New Governor Seeks Gas Line Two months after taking office, Alaska's first female governor, and its youngest ever, wants to deliver on a long-promised $30 billion pipeline to bring natural gas from the state's North Slope to markets in the Lower 48 states. A10 Airlines and Liquor Laws After a US Airways passenger who drank on his flight caused a gruesome car wreck in New Mexico that killed six, officials there have taken steps to ensure that airlines fully comply with liquor laws. Several airlines do not have liquor licenses in the state. A10 5 Die in Weekend Avalanches Avalanches in the interior West killed five people over the weekend, including four snowmobilers. Two snowmobilers died in Montana's Big Belt Mountains, and two in Utah: one near Palisades Peak and another on Signal Peak. A12 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Patron of African misgovernment; New York's bully governor; making martial law easier; don't fall for hot-pink camels. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Housing Market Heats Up In New York A burst of activity has broken out in Manhattan and Brooklyn as New Yorkers hunt for co-ops, condominiums and town houses, sending prices higher despite sluggish sales in many other cities. Thanks to pent-up demand from New Yorkers who were once worried that the city's real estate market would crash, buyers' attitudes have done an about-face. A1 Officer's Life Upended Jacqueline Melendez Rivera, a 13-year member of the New York Police Department, has been charged with covering up for her husband, who is accused of shooting a plainclothes officer. To people who know Officer Rivera, a decorated war veteran who is pregnant with her fourth child, the accusations are baffling. B1 Casino Battle in Buffalo The Seneca Indians intend to open a 6,000-square-foot gambling hall in Buffalo, a city from which jobs and residents continue to flee. But many business and political leaders think the casino would topple Buffalo's shaky economy because the Seneca, like other tribes, do not have to pay property or sales taxes. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Kevin Harvick Wins at Daytona Kevin Harvick defeated Mark Martin by little less than the front hood of his racecar to win a crash-filled Daytona 500, the opening race of the Nextel Cup season. D1 Football Star Opts for Baseball Jeff Samardzija, a standout wide receiver for Notre Dame, chose professional baseball over a career in the N.F.L., which he was widely expected to enter in April with the attendant fanfare of a first- or second-round draft pick. D2 ARTS E1-12 Restoring a Legendary Painting ''Washington Crossing the Delaware,'' one of the largest paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 21 feet wide and 12 feet high, is undergoing one of the most complex restoration and reframing projects in the history of the museum. E1 OBITUARIES B8 Maurice Papon A prominent French functionary convicted in 1998 of complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity during the German occupation in World War II, he was 96. B8 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Monitoring Web Media Content-recognition software, a new technology that makes it possible to identify copyrighted material, could address what the entertainment industry sees as one of its biggest problems -- songs and videos being uploaded to the Web without permission. C1 Music Labels' New Approach Music companies, faced with widespread piracy and plunging sales, are linking with the very file-sharing networks that they have long viewed as piracy bazaars. C1 Joining the Oscar Party The pre-Oscar drumbeat seemsparticularly intense this year as Web sites of newspapers and magazines have begun aggressively courting all those multitaskers who watch television and surf the Web at the same time. C1 Movie Piracy in Canada An analysis by the Motion Picture Association of America has found that 30 to 40 percent of the bootleg DVDs sold in the United States were made by camcorders smuggled into Canadian theaters. C3 Business Digest C2 Bridge E11 Crossword E9 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E12 Weather D8
